column2: And if they're not having fun... Sometimes there's nothing you can do. You have to give yourself permission to say:
Okay. Maybe it wasn't meant to be. We'll talk more about this in the next video, but I think one of the biggest mistakes people make Is to assume any group of players could all have fun together
If only you were a good enough DM. If only I had paid more attention to what my players like If only I had more time to prepare the stuff they like
No. It's actually very hard to grab a random group of musicians and make a band out of them. There are very few bands like Rush, where they all get along for forty years

Most bands are like The Police, and they hate each other. You get a few good albums out of them and you count yourself lucky that it lasted that long. So when you get your band together for the first time
Absolutely be critical of your own work as the DM You will spend the rest of your life getting better. Absolutely pay attention to your players and try to learn what they like
So you can put the content in front of them that engages them. But be open to the possibility that it was not meant to be. And this is not a failing on your part.
Sometimes, the book you want to write is not the one they want to read. Doesn't mean that it's a bad book or that they're bad readers. Okay, different types of players

There's the accepted answer and my answer, and my answer is shorter, so we'll start with that. I break everyone down into two categories: Players and audience members. Players engage with the game. They have goals, they want to get stuff done.

Maybe they want to advance their own agenda, maybe they want to stop the bad guys But they're the ones who think about the game outside the game. These folks make the world go around. I run D&D for them. It doesn't matter if they want to develop their character, get more magic, more levels
Or join an organization, or stop a bad guy, or build a stronghold These are the folks I run D&D for. Other players are audience members. They are perfectly happy

And this is an important point, so I'm gonna repeat it for emphasis They are perfectly happy just watching the story unfold and taking their turn in combat and otherwise never engaging with the game. When I was starting out, I thought this was a problem. Why isn't that player engaging? I must be doing something wrong.
Or, a most treacherous thought: They must be doing something wrong. No. Wrong. Nonsense. If they're having fun, you did your job. You will notice them sit back, watch everything unfold and think:

This is cool. They'll even say: "This is cool." That means they're having fun. Congratulations. Thomas Aquinas said that when you look at a painting, you don't see the painting, you see a version of it that you built in your head.

And that version in your head is missing details the artist painted And you may see things they didn't paint, make connections or see context they didn't intend. Aquinas said that the viewers act of creation is just as valid as the one the painter experienced.

It's not the artist's job to say "No, you got it wrong". The work has to speak for itself. Your audience members are building their own version of your world in their heads. To you, they seem disengaged. They have no motivation, they don't seem to care about your plot or NPCs.

But they built this amazing version of your world in their heads. Let them do that. Let them appreciate it, it is a perfectly valid thing to do. Maybe they'll eventually engage, but if it happens, it will happen on their terms.

Do not try to force it. Some players who are audience members in this game become players in another. As long as you got some players and not all audience members,  your game is gonna be fine. Okay, that's my answer. You gaot players and audience members and in the next episode we will talk how to engage your players

But you should expect some of the folks in your table to be audience members, and if you try to convert them, you'll end up both frustrated and unhappy. If they're having fun, you did good. That's maybe the biggest lesson I've learned over the last thirty years that I've didn't read somewhere

I had to figure it out for myself, and hopefully, I've just saved you some headaches. Now for the official answer: There's a guy named Robin Laws, smart guy, made his bones in the nineties on games like Over the edge and Feng Shui

And nowadays makes a great roleplaying game that has very little in common with D&D called GUMSHOE Actually, I think GUMSHOE is the system and there are different games that use it, like The Esoterrorists and Night's Black Agents I'll put the links to those in the Doobli-Doo. If you're keen on RPGs, but aren't interested in fantasy or the tactical elements of D&D, you might really like these games.

I don't know Robin, but my friend Ken Hite wrote Night's Black Agents. Hi Ken! Robin identified several different types of gamers based on an earlier list by a dude named Glenn Blacow Glenn's list appeared in an article from a magazine called Different Worlds published by Chaosium, that lauched a lot of people's carreers back in the eighties.
That's your chunck of RPG history for the day. So, in no particular order, Robin Laws's seven types of gamers plus one or two of my own. #1: The Powergamer

This player basically wants their character to be Thor. Invincible, powerful, badass weapon, fun, for them, is knowing my character is as badass as he can be. And they see your game and the rules as an opportunity to do this.

They engage with the rules because they see the rules as a problem to solve. I often call these players engineers. They want to learn the system so they can max it out. We used to call these guys Munchkins, from wich this card game gets its name

But that's pejorative. MinMaxer is still a popular term, less pejorative I've been a MinMaxer in my time It's easy to engage a player like this, just plant some badass item into your world that will make them the best paladin, or monk, or whatever their class is, and let them quest for it. Then, eventually, let them find it. Let them be badass, do not try and teach them a lesson, do not try and smack them down.
I often, often, see DMs act like a powergamer is somehow challenging them That player doesn't respect my setting, they don't respect my badass NPCs, I'll show them! No, do not do that.

Your NPCs are not there to kick the ass of the PCs, unless that's a plot point you were aiming for, but that's different We'll talk about that in another episode: Setting up bad guys Power gamers tendo to get frustrated if they don't get the chance to use their cool habilities, so

Give them a chance to use their cool habilities. Set up difficult scenarios, and when the powergamer wins, they'll feel awesome When I detect that kind of player, I will often give the bad guy just enough hit points to keep them alive, until the powergamer can kill him dramatically with a cool hability #2: The Buttkicker
Also known as the murderhobo. Often a very social player. Wants to show up, relax with friends and kill stuff. Had a long day and likes pretending to be a badass character who kills stuff

Gets frustrated when too much time passes without... killing stuff. Killing stuff can also mean: get something done, so these folks sometimes feel satisfied if they solve a problem; complete a quest, But mostly, for these folks, D&D is rolling dice and killing orcs.

They get bored or frustrated talking to NPCs or dealing with puzzles. They're often not interested in nuances. I had a situation in a game where one player was questioning a hapless captive and another player said "This is boring, I execute the guy."

Okay, that was a conflict between one player and the buttkicker. The buttkicker got bored listening to the blah-blah and acted. The other player, by the way, stopped playing after that and later told me he didn't realized D&D was a game where one player could ruin another player's fun.
That was a failing of mine. I should have massaged the situation so that the negotiation wrapped up in a satisfying way So the first player gets what he wants and the buttkicker doesn't get bored.
I very badly misread that situation. I am mortal. #3: The Tactician Related to the murderhobo and Thor,

The tactician wants to manage everyone. They don't necessarily want to minmax their character, they want to minmax your adventure. They plan a lot. I love these players. In my games, characters without plans... fail.

But they tend to want to second guess everyone else's decisions They don't just want their character to do the optimal thing, they want the team to do the optimal thing. They pick up other player's minis and say: "No, you should move over here!"

They say: "Why don't you use that magic item? It's better than the weapon you're using." Now, the fact that they like doing that doesn't mean that they're good at it. Or that the other players enjoy it.

Because tacticians gets frustrated when other players don't do what the tactician percieves as the optimal thing, They nag the other players, and hound them. And this is bad. They get upset when another player does something in character, but suboptimal.

These players need to learn that not everyone wants their advice. I mean, I know a lot of players who also want to do the optimal thing, they just want to learn what that is through trial and error rather than just following someone's orders.

You may notice these players tend not to care over much about their character's personality or background For the tactician, the key to their fun is the rate of success of their plans. If their plan goes awry, it may not matter if you have a perfectly good explanation.

They appreciate and prefer a logical world with characters and scenarios that behaves in accordance to their expectations. Tacticians get an idea in their head about what should happen based on your description of the scenario and get frustrated if their plan fails for any reason other than "the dice went against them".

I've noticed these players tend to be the ones who want to try to trick me. You will experience this. Your players will say: "No, no, no, don't give our plan away" They believe that telling you their plan just gives you more time to find a way to thwart it.

And, I mean, there are DMs out there who do that I'm not one of them, and probably, neither are you, My job as a DM is not to solve the players problems, it's to solve their solutions. The players come up with crazy solutions to problems and it's up to you to gently remind them of things they've forgotten

Or details about the scenario they either didn't notice or that they wrongly assumed weren't relevant when you've set it up. Things they can't know? Don't explain. You aren't obligated to make their plan work, you're only obligated to make sure they don't do something dumb just because they forgotten something
or they've wrongly assumed some detail. I often tell the players: "That's a good idea!" when they tell me their plan, if I think it's a good idea. But then I explain that nothing is certain.
I will never try and thwart the players just to thwart them, that's insane Though they sometimes perceive it that way because I'm running all the bad guys. I say, and I mean it:

I'm not trying to kill you, this mind flayer is trying to kill you. It's funny, but it's an important point: My goal is not to kill the PCs, that's ridiculous, is to run the bad guys as realistically as it's reasonable. And the bad guys want to win.
Anyway, player types. #4: The specialist Some players, if they have a cool character, can have fun just playing their character.

Nothing else matters, they can have fun in a game they otherwise don't care about because their character is cool. But the specialis only has fun if they play this one character. It's the same character they always play in every game, with the same name, usually.
I've seen specialists with tunnel vision so bad they want to play their sci-fi anime character in this medieval european game. At first, your reaction is bafflement. "What is going on?", you wonder.

Then you tease out this is the character this player runs. For these folks, an RPG is an opportunity for them to play this character they always fantasized about being. I sometimesthink the reason they keep doing it, the reason they have this specialty is beacuse no game has really let them do it.

Of course not. D&D is not designed to let you play a character from Bubblegum Crisis. is that obscure these days? What's popular? One Punch Man, you get it. It's pretty easy to detect these players because of how weird their character is.

It's the reason I developed my 4d6 in order method, to force players discover their characters rather than bring their baggage to my table. But that's my taste, it's perfectly possible to let their player run their specialty. Be a ninja, or a shapeshifter, or whatever.
There may not be an class for it, but you can usually take an existing one and bend it a little. You can make Wolverine in D&D with a little creativity. #5: The actor

Has a highly developed notion of who their character is and loves playing in character. That's the juice for the actor. Often writes an elaborate backstory, though, an elaborate backstory is not a sign of an actor. They usually want to play an flamboyant hero, but not always. Sometimes an actor wants to play the man with no name.

Like the specialist, this player often gets frustrated when their idea of teir character story is not supported by the rules. They often see the rules as a nuisance, and prefer a session where the dice never came out. The good actor players see the dice as stimuli for improvisation. The troublesome actor players see the dice as the enemy.

They had a good story in their head and the dice ruined it. For players like this, read their backstory. Use things from it. Give them NPCs to show off to. Pick an element of their backstory and weave it into your game. Give them some opportunities to roleplay that don't rely on the dice.
Actors care more about "What would my character do" than they do your world or rules. This can sometimes exasperate the other players. "But I'm just playing my character!", they say.

Don't mistake the actor from the wangrod. I want to use another word there but I'm trying to keep this channel family-friendly. The wangrod uses D&d as an opportunity to be mean. Cruel. And when challenged on this, says: "That's what my character would do!" When the actor says this, they mean it. They though a lot about their character and when challenged on it, it's usually by the tactician
Who just wants them to do the mechanicaly optimal thing. "But that's not what my character would do" That player I like! We all like players who would rather do the sub-optimal but in-character thing

Than something drastically out of character just to gain some mechanical benefit. But that's not what happening with the wangrod. The wangrod just wants to inflict pain, sometimes on the other players, and when challenged, they resort to this defense.

I'm just doing what my character would do! They've somehow sussed out that this is an airtight defense. But, of course, it's not. "Well, your character is being a wangrod an is ruining our fun" is the answer.
Sometimes you have to confront a problem head on. By no means a wangrod is a sadist in real life. This is important. Indulging a fantasy of cruelty is different from the real thing. I think.
I mean, I'm not a psychologist, I could be wrong. One of the most common complains from new DMs is: "My players won't role-play." But not every player is an actor. Most aren't.

That's okay. You don't have to talk in character to play D&D and have fun. If someone's not comfortable in getting into character, that's fine, it's not a problem to solve. Give them space, don't put them on the spot and maybe something will come out.

Some role-playing will happen. If not, that's fine. The funny thing is: I've actually played with real actors and at least in the case of Liam and Matt Mercer and Marisha The only difference between them and other gamers was they narrated their characters successes and failures.

Took a second to get used to, because tipically, that's my job, but WOW it made my job easier and the game was way more fun for me. I wish everyone would do that. But, for most players, hearing me narrate their success or failure is what makes it real. #6: The storyteller

Has a lot in common with the actor, but while the actor is primarily focused in role-playing their character, The storyteller wants the most dramatically satisfying outcome possible. The tactician needs to know: "This is what would have happened".

They don't like detecting the hand of the DM in there adjusting things to stop the PCs from dying Or keep a bad guy alive long enough to do their thing, they need to feel like the outcome of the encounter, For good or ill, is the mos plausible one according to the rules of the game and your own world.

The storyteller needs to know the dramatticaly appropriate thing happened. This player doesn't mind losing a character as long as their death was dramatically appropriate. The storyteller wants the game to behave like a movie. They're only interested in the rules so far as they support this.

Storytellers will change their characters personality if it means something dramatically satisfying happens. And here I don't mean drama like interpersonal conflict like teenage drama I mean drama as in narrative: Three acts, antagonist, protagonist, tension, resolution.
When this player gets an idea on their head of what shoud happen, dramatically, You better make sure it does. At least once in a while. Even if it's not what you have planned.

You'll detect this when the storyteller does something dramatic, risks their character's life to solve a problem. You thought there was another solution, you don't think the storyteller's solution is any good But... sometimes you got to compromise.
Let the game play the way the storyteller though it would every once in a while and they'll be happy. #7: The casual gamer I think this is basically the same as the audience member in my example.

The casual gamer is easy to make happy, they just want to show up, hang out with their friends and watch a cool story unfold. You know how to ruin this player's night?  Put him on the spot. Expect them to talk in character, expect them to negotiate with the NPC

You'll see them get uncomfortable and they'll often do something out of character just to get out of the situation. As we said before: Don't try and force one type of player into becoming another. Enjoy your audience members. They're enjoying your game.

I'm gonna add my own humble addition to this list: The mad scientist The mad scientist has a hard time taking all of this seriously. They have fun poking things just to see what happens, they often want to experiment with the world, and often,
the crazier the result, the better. Mad scientist, you understand: insane. Their characters behave in completely unrealistic ways, but so what? The game is literally not real, so who cares?
Why are you getting upset? It's just a game. Well, in point of fact, is a game you put a lot of of work into And that's the problem. The mad scientist is, by definition, disruptive.

They like being disruptive. To them, disrupting the world you built is fun. Because they don't get to do that in the real world. Very young players are often mad scientists. You have kids and you want to run D&D for them, but you don't want to wait until they're fifteen

So you start when they're nine, and as it turns out, nine year olds don't want to talk to anyone, they want to kill everyone. They want to do, in your game,  all the things they never get to do in real life. For them, that's the fun.

Now you've detected based on my description that I consider the mad scientist a problem player And I think that for a lot of DMs that's true, but not all DMs think that I've played in games that were explicitly for mad scientist players and it was a lot of fun

There are whole adventures written for these players, they used to call them Funhouse Dungeons Explicitly crazy. Just surviving is meant to be a reward. I think when we played as teenagers we often just ran around the DMs world doing crazy stuff

With no regard for logic or reason, and as long as funny or interesting things happened, we were happy. And, often, the DM was having just as much fun as the players. But as we get older, we tend to want more out of the game. If you got a mad scientis player, you may have to take them aside and say:

Listen , it's fun to screw around with stuff, but this is stuff I put a lot of work into, so it kills me alittle when you screw around with it. No player is one hundred percent any of these archetypes, and a lot of players object to being pigeon-holed As well as they should, but in my experience, these archetypes bear a rough corresponding to reality.
Finally, my last advice, the best advice I can give you Talk to your players. Talk about what games do they play, about what kinds of books they read or movies they like.

Tell them what kind of game you run. You'd be surprised with what you might learn. I don't think there's any problem you can't  solve by talking about it. Altough, the solution might be "okay, let's play Talisman"

let's play someting else where we'll all have fun and I don't have to bust my ass Sometimes it doesn't work out, and that's okay. Not every band is Rush. Allright, those are the different types of players Obviously, these aren't the only types of players

You can come up with your own list If I had sat down and spent the time I could probably come up with a completely different list It's always dangerous to try to categorize people But I remebmer when I read that list back in the nineties and I found it useful, so hopefully you'll find it useful too.

Hi everybody, my name is Matt Colville, and as you can see I am a white, middle-class, middle-aged nerd. And if you guessed, "I bet that guy plays D&D,"  you would be correct. This is my channel and it's about running Dungeons & Dragons.

and I think the effect he was going for was the voice of an omniscient narrator coming from nowhere. Except of course, it's coming from behind that screen which is kind of weird to me. And I remember when this article came out, a lot of people said they thought that was weird,

and then a lot of people came out of the woodwork who had played back in the early 1970s and said, "No, actually, a lot of people, including Gary Guygax ran the game from behind full-body screens, you wouldn't see them at all." I'm not sure how long that tradition lasted,

but the idea was that you were exploring the dungeon, not reading the Dungeon Master and that obscuring his face meant that you couldn't see what his reaction was to the things that you were doing. It also gave him the opportunity to change maps behind the screen, and you wouldn't even know that he was doing it.

So, that seems pretty weird to me, but I bet if I had played back then I would have thought it was pretty neat. So, my friend Jim Murphy has been running D&D since around then, around 1976, and he never uses a D.M. Screen.

He thinks of them as a kind of crutch, and also he doesn't like that feeling of being separated from the players. And, keep in mind, this is one of the best D.M.s I've ever played with. But, and uh, he's not here to defend himself - I actually interviewed him for this

in fact, maybe I will, maybe I'll go and have coffee with Jim and I'll do a little Q&A with him. So, if you have any questions for a guy who ran D&D back in 1976, let me know and I'll ask Jim. So, I think the reason Jim doesn't use a D.M. Screen, is that he feels it's a kind of cheat.

He feels like if the players see you rolling behind the screen, then they will think the results aren't real. Whereas, if he rolls the dice in front of you, then you all know that is objectively what would have happened. "I rolled a 20 for the orc, he critically hits you."

I didn't just decide the orc critically hits you because  you've had an easy time of it this evening, We all saw the die, it said 20, you were critically hit. And that is undeniably true. When the players see you, the D.M., rolling in front of them

they suddenly get apprehensive. That is a real roll, and there's nothing anyone can do about it once it's done. And that's probably the number one job of the D.M. Screen, is to give you, the D.M., the opportunity to roll behind the screen.

Jim does not have the opportunity to roll behind the screen, he does not have the opportunity to, as they call it, to fudge the die roles. Why would you want to fudge the die rolls? Why would you want to lie to your players?

Well, don't think of it as lying to your players; think of it as curating the experience. In fact, original D&D, back in 1974, the D.M. rolled all the dice. He rolled the dice for your character's stats when you made your character.
Right, I want you to think about that. You didn't get to make your own character. The D.M. rolled all your stats, he rolled your hit rolls, he rolled your damage rolls.
Now, again, that seems super weird to me, But, when you think about it, that means that D&D back then was a much more curated experience. Let's say you wanted to play a fighter.

I would tell you "Oh, yeah, no, I rolled an 18 strength for you, fantastic, but I got a 6 intelligence." Right, I could give you a character with stats that were good in the things they needed to be good in, but I could one or two things that were not that good to give you some interesting roll playing challenges.

We don't do it that way anymore, although I think there still is a good reason for the D.M. to make some rolls. For instance, one thing many D.M.s do, and I have done in the past and I probably will do in the future, is they'll make a little cheat sheet behind the screen with each P.C.s name on it

and they'll have on there what each character's perception bonus is and their stealth bonus is. So that when the player says "I'll hide in the shadows," they don't roll, you roll. Okay, why would you do that?

Because, I think there's an argument to be made that it's unrealistic for a player to know, "Is my character successfully hiding in the shadows?" It doesn't matter what you roll, your character certainly thinks he's hiding in the shadows.

As opposed to an athletics check. If you try to jump a chasm, you objectively know if you've failed or not. But, something like hiding, I think, your character doesn't know how well hidden he is, so why should the player? And then you get some interesting drama. The player starts to wonder, "Did I make it? Did I do a good job?"

Now, that's not to everybody's taste; I don't do that currently. But, I'm thinking about doing it again; I think my players would like it. And there's a good argument to be made for doing the same thing with perception.
when you tell the players, "Okay, make a perception check." You just told them that there was something to notice. And if they all fail, they know that they didn't notice it.
And that is another way to break their similitude, I think. Break suspension of disbelief. Suddenly the players go "Ah, what did we miss?"
Which is not really what you want them to be thinking. So, again, there's not a right way to do this stuff, these are just suggestions. These are things I know D.Ms do, things I've done as a D.M.

And, in fact, I got the idea from my friend, Brad, who was one of my favorite D.M.s, he ran for me when I was a teenager, And, I, as a player, really liked the style of play. So, my friend Jim Murphy doesn't use a D.M. Screen, he always rolls all his rolls in front of the players.

And, as a result, there's a lot more tension when he rolls, because you know it's real quote, unquote, but the flip side of that is, and I'm not making this up, almost every campaign Jim has started, began with a total party kill.

Or sometimes there was one survivor. Whatever. And that's because often, Jim starts a new campaign when there's a new edition of D&D out, and since it's a new edition of D&D, he doesn't know the rules that well yet.

I've actually had conversations with him after the fact where he said, "Wow, you know, I thought that four spectors wasn't going to be that hard for you guys." Because he remembers and edition of D&D where four spectors wasn't that hard for us.

And because he doesn't roll behind the D.M. screen he doesn't have an opportunity mid-combit to go, "Wow, this battle is a lot tougher than I thought. I didn't mean for it to be this hard." So that's one of the purposes of the D.M. Screen. It's to help hide your screw-ups.

You didn't mean for this combat to be this difficult, but because you are rolling behind the screen you have the opportunity to kind of miss every once in awhile, do less damage than the dice actually said to do.

And this is something where the first time you do it, it might be obvious, but after you've gotten the hang of it you'll know how to do it in such a way that your players don't notice. I've gotten to the point now, I've been doing this for a while, where I generally roll in front of the players,
to increase that feeling of verisimilitude, but about 20-30 percent of the time, I roll behind the screen. And, most of the time the only reason I'm doing that,

is so that when I need to roll behind the screen it doesn't look so suspicious. Right, if you only every roll behind the screen, because you need to fudge a roll, your players will notice. One thing I try to avoid doing is fudging my dice to keep a bad guy alive just because I like them.

I also have on here each character's max hit points, and I would keep track of their current hit points over the course of the battle.

Now that does cost more work from your point of view as a D.M., and it may not be worth it for you, but I liked knowing what the players' current and total hit points were for a couple reasons. For one thing, as the P.C.s level up, the difference in their hit points starts to become significant,

and doing 20 points of damage to one character might bring them from full hit points to almost dead, whereas that same 20 points to another character might only take them to half damage. And it's useful to know, "Which character am I about to kill with this attack?"
Also, keeping track of the running total means you know when you are about to kill a character, and I find that is useful information. Now, the goal here isn't to kill or not kill characters.

The goal here is just to provide a plausible dramatic experience. And sometimes you may discover that your own ignorance, or the players' ignorance, or the dice, undermine that. I've had evenings where I couldn't roll less than a 17, and I realized, "If I keep doing this, the players are all going to die!"

This wasn't a tough encounter until I couldn't miss. The opposite also happens. They were expecting something dramatic, and in fact, it turns out to be not that memorable.

It's one of those things that, once you've done it a couple times, you start to get the hang of it, but when you know each character's current hit points, that gives you the opportunity to have the bad guys discreetly switch targets from one to the other, so you don't end up accidentally killing a character when you didn't mean to.

Lastly, I wrote down each character's saving throws, and I put a box around which one had the worst saving throw in each category, and that helped me making decisions running the bad guys. In a certain sense it's cheating, because obviously the bad guys don't know what the different character's saving throws are,

but in another sense, the bad guys, I think, are roughly as intelligent as the good guys, usually, and you can tell which of these characters is the priest, just like the good guys can tell which of the bad guys is the shaman, and typically the priest has a high wisdom save, so don't cast spells on that character that require wisdom save.

Just like you can tell the thief is the nimble, dexterous one; don't attack them with something that requires a reflex save. I think it's reasonable to assume you can tell by looking at a character which one's the smart one, which one's the nimble one, which one's the heavily armored one, and make decisions accordingly.
